meaningMnemonic: This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means <kanji>go</kanji>. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the き to help you to remember that this word means <vocabulary>train direction</vocabulary> (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (き) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "<vocabulary>bound for</vocabulary>" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
readingMnemonic:
The reading is also an exception. It can be いき, but instead we're focusing on the ゆき reading. You have to remember the ゆ portion, so think of it this way: 

Just think about the <vocabulary>train direction</vocabulary> that <reading>you</reading> (ゆ) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.
